definitions.definition: The ability to do or undergo something.
examples: He has lost the power to speak.

definitions.definition: The ability to coerce , influence , or control .

subdefinitions.definition: The ability to affect or influence .
examples: the power of the written word

subdefinitions.definition: The ability or authority to control , govern , command , coerce , etc., such as in a legal , political or business sphere.
examples: He's nominally president, but he does not have any real power .

subdefinitions.definition: The people in charge of legal or political power, the government.
A strong or influential nation, company, or other such body.
examples: In the 19th century, Britain and France were major colonial powers .
Britain is no longer the maritime power that it once was.
He needed a lot of power to hit the ball out of the stadium.

subdefinitions.definition: Designating one who does something forcefully or on a large or grand scale.
examples: She's a power shopper; she knows all the best deals.
This high-spec computer is ideal for power users.

subdefinitions.definition: The production or flow of energy providing means to do work ; energy per time unit.
examples: The power to haul the train is supplied by two huge locomotives.

subdefinitions.definition: Electricity or a supply of electricity.
examples: After the pylons collapsed, this town was without power for a few days.

subdefinitions.definition: The rate at which work is done or energy is transferred , expressed in units of energy per unit of time.
examples: The kilowatt is a unit of power , equivalent to 1,000 joules of energy per second.

subdefinitions.definition: The strength by which a lens or mirror magnifies an optical image .
examples: We need a microscope with higher power .

labels: dated outside the phrase 'power of good'
definitions.label_groups: colloquial , dated outside the phrase 'power of good'

definitions.definition: Any of the elementary forms or parts of machines: three primary (the lever, inclined plane, and pulley) and three secondary (the wheel-and-axle, wedge, and screw).

examples: The set I'm making right now needs a power on it, but we don't have any tractors left in the yard.

definitions.definition: A measure of the effectiveness that a force producing a physical effect has over time. If linear , the quotient of: ( force multiplied by the displacement of or in an object) ÷ time. If rotational , the quotient of: ( force multiplied by the angle of displacement ) ÷ time.

subdefinitions.definition: A product of equal factors (and generalizations of this notion): x n {\displaystyle x^{n}} , read as " x {\displaystyle x} to the power of n {\displaystyle n} " or the like, is called a power and denotes the product x × x × ⋯ × x {\displaystyle x\times x\times \cdots \times x} , where x {\displaystyle x} appears n {\displaystyle n} times in the product; x {\displaystyle x} is called the base and n {\displaystyle n} the exponent .
The probability that a statistical test will reject the null hypothesis when the alternative hypothesis is true.

definitions.definition: In Christian angelology , an intermediate level of angels , ranked above archangels , but exact position varies by classification scheme.

main_definition: The ability to do or undergo something.
secondary_definitions: ( social ) The ability to coerce , influence , or control .
( colloquial , dated outside the phrase 'power of good' ) A large amount or number.
Any of the elementary forms or parts of machines: three primary (the lever, inclined plane, and pulley) and three secondary (the wheel-and-axle, wedge, and screw).

( physics , mechanics ) A measure of the effectiveness that a force producing a physical effect has over time. If linear , the quotient of: ( force multiplied by the displacement of or in an object) ÷ time. If rotational , the quotient of: ( force multiplied by the angle of displacement ) ÷ time.
( biblical , in the plural ) In Christian angelology , an intermediate level of angels , ranked above archangels , but exact position varies by classification scheme.
